R. China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract NH3-SCR of NO on the (001) and (101) facets of anatase TiO2. Recently, the facet-dependent catalytic activity of anatase TiO2 for the selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 (NH3-SCR) has been observed experimentally. In this study, the NH3-SCR of NO on the TiO2 (001) and (101) surfaces was systematically investigated using dispersion-corrected density functional theory. We propose that the surface-assisted mechanism is predominant on the (001) surface, which involves the oxygen active sites playing a crucial role in facilitating the reaction. The NH3 dissociation step reveals the largest activation energy barrier (E a) of 61 kJ/mol on the (001) surface, whereas the NH2NO decomposition step has the largest barrier, E a ≈ 156 kJ/mol, on the (101) surface. The results obtained by calculation are consistent with the experimental results, which have shown that a TiO2 nanosheet with a dominant (001) facet shows superior catalytic performance in NH3-SCR of NO compared to TiO2 nanoparticles with dominant (101) facet. Keywords NH3-SCR NO Anatase TiO2 (001) Anatase TiO2 (101) Density functional theory 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NO x ) are major pollutants produced by combustion processes and have a significant and negative effect on the global environment and human health. Nitric oxide or nitrogen monoxide (NO) is one of the well-known NOx species that can undergo reactions to form a range of toxic chemicals, acid rain, and photochemical smog [1,2]. Therefore, methods to remove NO from exhaust gases are urgently required. Among the various approaches, the selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 (NH3-SCR of NO) has been widely utilized to eliminate NO from exhaust gases produced by combustion sources. In the NH3-SCR method, NH3 is used as a reducing agent to convert NO into the environmentally benign products N2 and H2O. The NH3-SCR reaction is very complex for which many possible mechanisms were proposed [2,3]. For example, the standard SCR reaction, 4NO + 4NH3 + O2 → 4N2 + 6H2O, represents stoichiometry with equimolar amounts of NO and NH3 in the presence of oxygen. The so-called fast SCR reaction, 4NH3 + 2NO +2NO2 → 4N2 + 6H2O, represents the reduction of equimolar amounts of NO and NO2. Other possible reactions of the reduction of NO and NO2 by NH3 are 4NH3 + 2NO2+ O2 → 3N2 + 6H2O, 4NH3+ 6NO → 5N2 + 6H2O, and 8NH3 + 6NO2 → 7N2 + 12H2O [2]. In addition, the reaction mechanism can possibly proceed via different intermediates (i.e. NH2NO, NH4NO2, NH4NO3) in different catalytic systems [2,3]. Supported V2O5, such as TiO2-supported V2O5-WO3 and V2O5-MoO3, is used commercially as an industrial NH3-SCR catalyst [4]. Although their NOx removal efficiency is high at 300–400 °C, these V-based catalysts still suffer from the poisoning of SO2/alkali/alkaline-earth metals, toxicity of vanadium species, and the narrow operating temperature window, especially at low temperature range (<250 °C) [2]. These aspects prohibit the use of V-based catalysts in many applications such as diesel engine, glass, steel, and cement plants [2]. Therefore, other V-free oxide catalysts, such as titanium oxide [5–7], iron oxide [8–11], cerium oxide [12,13], and manganese oxide [14,15], as well as mixed metal oxides [16–18], have drawn attention as catalysts for the NH3-SCR of NO. However, achieving high NH3-SCR activity for metal oxide catalysts remains challenging, despite numerous attempts to increase the activity by, for example, modifying the catalyst morphology [14,18] or doping [17,19,20]. Theoretical studies have also been performed to elucidate the NH3-SCR mechanism in various systems, and it has been shown that the reaction mechanism of NH3-SCR of NO is highly catalyst-dependent. For example, the NH3-SCR of NO over Mn-doped CeO2 (111) [21] and V2O5 (010) surfaces proceed via the Eley–Rideal (ER) mechanism [22], while the Langmuir–Hinshelwood (LH) mechanism is dominant for the NH3-SCR of NO over W-doped CeO2 [23]. Therefore, it is crucial to obtain a mechanistic understanding of NH3-SCR for a range of catalysts to enable their design and development and ensure high activities and selectivities. Titanium oxides have a wide range of applications, e.g. as supports, thermal catalysts, and photocatalysts [24–30]. Titanium oxide has three main polymorphs: anatase, rutile, and brookite, and crystals of the anatase polymorph have a dominant (101) facet (>98 % of total area) because of its high thermodynamic stability. In contrast, the (001) facet is rarely observed. However, the (001) surface exhibits better reactivity than the (101) facet [31,32]. Thus, experimentalists have attempted to synthesize anatase crystals having larger (001) facets, and materials having an abundance of the (001) surface have been reported [33,34]. Furthermore, it has been proposed that this facet shows high catalytic activity for many reactions, such as photocatalytic CO2 reduction [28], H2S desulfurization [29], and the methanol-to-dimethyl ether (DME) reaction [30]. In addition, for the NH3-SCR of NO, anatase TiO2 has been used as both a support and catalyst [5–7,35,36]. In our previous studies, the morphologically dependent catalytic activity of anatase TiO2 was observed experimentally [7,36]. Specifically, TiO2 nanosheets (TiO2-NSs) were found to show superior NH3-SCR activity for NO reduction compared to TiO2 nanoparticles (TiO2-NPs), even at low temperatures. The characterization of these catalysts revealed that the TiO2-NSs have dominant (001) facets, whereas the (101) facet is predominant in the TiO2-NPs [36]. Furthermore, preliminary calculations revealed that the TiO2 (001) surface adsorbs NH3 and NO more strongly than the (101) surface, and this is related to the more active Oα species observed in the TiO2-NSs than those in the TiO2-NPs [36]. Although the adsorption of gaseous species was investigated in our previous study, the reaction mechanism and origin of the high catalytic activity of the (001) surface remain poorly understood. In this study, the NH3-SCR of NO over an anatase TiO2 catalyst was investigated using dispersion-corrected density functional theory (DFT) calculations. To understand the origin of the high catalytic activity of the anatase TiO2 (001) surface, the electronic structure, geometric characteristics, and the reaction mechanism of the anatase TiO2 (001) and (101) facets were compared, and special focus was given to the active sites. According to our previous experimental work [36], in situ diffuse reflectance infrared transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) of NH3 adsorption showed that the coordination of NH3 with the Lewis acid site is predominant in both TiO2-NS and TiO2-NP catalysts. Small band corresponding to Brønsted acid sites (or hydroxyl groups, −OH) was observed. Lewis acid sites were quite stable at the temperature range from 30 °C to 400 °C. In addition, the bulk terminated surface was used for representing the (001) surface in this work, because the reconstructed TiO2 (1 × 4)-(001) surface is required harsher controlled conditions [37,38] than the conditions used in our previous work [36]. Therefore, we focused on the de-hydroxylated/bulk terminated surfaces in this work. The results presented herein provide detailed physical insights that will assist the further development of metal oxide catalysts for NO removal. 2 Computational methods The plane-wave DFT calculations were performed using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [39,40]. The projector-augmented wave (PAW) method [41] and the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange and correlation functional were used [42]. In addition, the calculations were dispersion corrected using Grimme’s DFT-D3 empirical correction [43]. In all the calculations, the energy convergence was 1 × 10−6 eV/cell, the force convergence was 2.5 × 10-3 eV/Å, and the energy cutoff was 400 eV; all the calculations were spin unrestricted. The structure of bulk anatase TiO2 was optimized using a 12 × 12 × 6 Monkhorst–Pack grid. A slab of anatase TiO2 (001) was built from the optimized bulk anatase TiO2 structure, which has tetragonal I41/amd symmetry. The lattice constants of this model are a = b =3.79 Å and c =9.40 Å and are consistent with the experimental values (a = b =3.78 Å and c =9.51 Å) [44,45]. A (2 × 2) slab of the anatase TiO2 (001) surface and a (1 × 2) slab of the anatase TiO2 (101) surface were separated from their replicas in the periodic boundary calculations by a vacuum gap of 12 Å. The anatase TiO2 (001) surface slab having a = b =7.57 Å containes of 48 atoms and four Ti layers. For the anatase TiO2 (101) surface, the slab surface has lattice parameters of a =10.22 Å and b =7.57 Å and consistes of three Ti layers with a total of 72 atoms. The bottom two Ti layers were fixed during the calculations in both slab models. The bulk model and two slab structures are shown Fig. 1 . As shown in this figure, the anatase TiO2 (101) surface has four different sites: two-fold-coordinate oxygen (O2c), three-fold-coordinate oxygen (O3c), five-fold-coordinate titanium (Ti5c), and six-fold-coordinate titanium (Ti6c) (Fig. 1c). The adsorption sites of the anatase TiO2 (001) surface are the O2c, O3c, and Ti5c sites (Fig. 1b). The O2c and Ti5c sites act as the active adsorption sites on both surfaces. For the (001) and (101) surfaces, Monkhorst–Pack grids having dimensions of 6 × 6 × 1 and 4 × 6 × 1, respectively, were used. The adsorption energies of the reactants, intermediates, and products on the two surfaces were calculated to assess the binding strength between the adsorbates and surfaces. The adsorption energy (E ad) was calculated using Eq. (1). (1) E ad = E adsorbate-surface − E surface isolated − E adsorbate isolated Here, E adsorbate-surface is the total energy of the adsorbate-surface system, and E surface isolated and E surface isolated are the total energies of the bare surface and an isolated adsorbate molecule, respectively. The transition states in the energy profiles were located using the climbing-image nudged elastic band (CINEB) method [46,47]. In some cases, the dimer method [48,49] was used to refine the transition state search. The criterion for force convergence was less than 0.025 eV/Å. Each identified transition state was confirmed to be a true transition state using frequency analysis (i.e., the presence of a single imaginary frequency). The activation energy (E a) is the difference between the total energies of the transition state (E TS) and the initial state (E IS) of each step. The reaction energy (E rxn) is the difference in energy between the final state (E FS) and the initial state (E IS). The Bader charges [50,51] were used for the partial charges, and the partial density of states (PDOS) of each system was calculated to interpret the reactivity of the catalysts. 3 Results and discussion In this study, the reaction mechanisms for the NH3-SCR of NO on the anatase TiO2 (001) and (101) surfaces were investigated. In the following sections, first, the electronic structure and geometric characteristics of the two surfaces are compared, focusing on the active sites, followed by a discussion of the adsorption energies of the relevant species. Next, the energy profiles of the possible reaction pathways for the NH3-SCR on the (001) and (101) surfaces are discussed. Lastly, we compare the NH3-SCR of NO on the (001) and (101) surfaces and identify the reasons for the high catalytic activity of the (001) surface. 3.1 Electronic structures of the anatase TiO2 (001) and (101) surfaces First, we discuss the geometric characteristics and partial charges of the surface sites shown in the models in Fig. 1. In the structure of the TiO2 (001) facet, each Ti5c surface atom is coordinated to two O2c atoms and two O3c atoms of the top layer. In contrast, in the structure of the TiO2 (101) facet, each Ti5c surface atom is coordinated to one O2c atom and three O3c atoms of the top layer. The accessible Ti6c sites are only presented in the top layer of the TiO2 (101) surface model, whereas the Ti6c sites of the (001) model are presented in the sub layers and bulk region. The Ti5c and O2c sites are the active catalytic sites on both surfaces because of their lower coordination numbers than those of the Ti6c and O3c sites. To investigate the active sites further, Bader charge analysis was performed on the bare surfaces. Here, positive and negative values indicate decreases and increases, respectively, in the number of valence electrons compared to neutral atoms. The partial charges of the Ti5c and O2c sites on the (001) surface are +2.07 and −1.03 |e|, respectively, whereas, on the (101) surface, they are +2.16 and −0.98 |e|, respectively. As shown later, the Ti and O sites act as Lewis acid and Brønsted base sites, respectively, and the charge polarization is more significant on the (101) surface. The PDOS of the Ti5c and O (O2c and O3c) sites on the (001) and (101) surfaces were calculated, and the results are shown in Fig. 2 . The middle of the band gap energy (E g) of each surface is aligned at 0 eV. The (001) surface has the narrower E g than the (101) surface, approximately 0.53 eV. As shown in the PDOS, the valence band maximum of the (001) surface is dominated by the O2c atoms. In addition, the conduction band minimum of the (001) surface predominantly comprises contributions from the Ti5c orbitals. The upper edge of valence band was proposed to be the origin of the greater reactivity of the O2c sites on the (001) surface than those of the (101) surface and bulk anatase TiO2 [25]. Considering the importance of orbital interactions of surface active sites with adsorbates, these results suggest that the (001) surface is more reactive than the (101) surface. 3.2 Gas adsorption on the anatase TiO2 (001) and (101) surfaces The adsorption energies of various adsorbates that are relevant to the present reaction system were calculated for both the anatase TiO2 (001) and (101) surfaces. The calculated E ad values of the most stable structures on these surfaces are summarized in Table 1 , and the corresponding structures are displayed in Figs. S1 and S2 in Supplementary Information (SI). Based on the adsorption energies, the Ti5c and O2c sites are the active sites for the gas adsorption process. In general, the Ti5c and O2c sites of TiO2 act as Lewis acid and Brønsted base sites, respectively. Further, the Ti5c sites are preferred for NH3 and N2 adsorption because the lone pair electrons of the N atoms can interact with the Lewis acidic Ti5c sites. In contrast, the Brønsted basicity of O2c makes the formation of hydroxyl groups favorable after proton dissociation from the adsorbates. The E ad values indicate that the (001) surface is more active than the (101) surface for all adsorbates, which is consistent with the trends observed in the valence and conduction bands of the PDOS but not with the partial charges of the Ti5c sites. For the gas/TiO2 (001) systems, the adsorption strength decreases in the order of H2O (dissociative adsorption) > NH3 (molecular adsorption) > NH3 (dissociative adsorption) > NO > NO2 > N2 > O2, whereas, for the TiO2 (101) case, it decreases in the order of NH3 (molecular adsorption) > H2O (molecular adsorption) > H2O (dissociative adsorption) > NO > NO2 > N2 > O2 > NH3 (dissociative adsorption). The (001) surface is very active for the adsorption of H2O. In fact, water is dissociatively adsorbed on the surface with an E ad of −162.6 kJ/mol, and the molecular adsorption of H2O on the (001) surface was not observed in our calculations. After dissociative adsorption, the OH group is bound to a Ti5c site, and the H atom reacts with the nearest O2c atom to form a new OH group. In this work, the water coverage (Θ), which is defined as the ratio of the number of adsorbed H2O molecules to the number of Ti5c sites on the surface, was 0.25. Based on the E ad values calculated in this study, the molecular adsorption of water is more favorable on the (101) facet than dissociative adsorption. This finding is consistent with the results of other studies [56]. In contrast, the molecular adsorption of NH3 was found to be more energetically favorable than dissociative adsorption on both surfaces. The Lewis acidic Ti5c sites are the binding sites for NH3, and the E ad for NH3 on the (001) surface is larger than that on the (101) surface. As discussed in the previous section, the orbital interactions are more important for determining the adsorption preferences on these surfaces than the charge polarization at the Ti5c sites. Geometric factors are also important: for example, the presence of favorable interactions between NH3 and the nearest O2c site can enhance the adsorption of NH3 on the (001) surface. Thus, the dissociative adsorption of NH3 is more favorable on the (001) surface than on the (101) surface. These results agree well with those of previous studies (Table 1). On the other hand, the dissociative adsorption of NH3 on the (101) surface is not as favorable thermodynamically, as shown by its lower E ad (−11.60 kJ/mol). This result explains the higher reactivity of the O2c sites on the (001) surface. From the H2O adsorption, the dissociative adsorption of H2O is favorable leading to the hydroxylation on the (001) surface. We examined the NH3 adsorption on the hydroxylated (001) surface with Θ = 0.5 shown in Fig. S3 in SI. The NH4 + formation with the E ad of −91.79 kJ/mol can be observed when NH3 interacts with the Brønsted acid site. The preferences for the adsorption of NO, NO2, N2 and O2 show similar trends for both surfaces. Overall, the trends in the adsorption energies and structures of the relevant species are consistent with the literature results summarized in Table 1. However, there are some discrepancies, possibly originating from differences in the sizes of the computational models and the adsorbate coverage. Importantly, our calculations included dispersion correction using Grimme’s DFT-D3 method, and this was found to improve the E ad values by 10–30 kJ/mol compared to those without corrections. 3.3 Reduction of NO via the NH3-SCR on the anatase TiO2 (001) surface Due to the complexity of the NH3-SCR of NO, many possible reaction pathways via different intermediates (i.e. NH2NO, NH4NO2, NH4NO3) would occur as mentioned in the introduction [2,3]. This work aims to clarify the different behavior of active sites on two surfaces which leads to the different catalytic activity for the reduction of NO by NH3. We focused on the possible pathways in which NH2NO plays a key role as an intermediate in the SCR reaction in TiO2 [60]. Some other possible reaction mechanisms including NO2 are not considered but need to be examined in future work. Herein, the reduction of NO by NH3-SCR involves three main steps (Eqs. 2–4). The first step is the dissociation of NH3 on the surface (Eq. 2), the second step is the generation of nitrosamine (NH2NO) (Eq. 3), and the third step is the dissociation of NH2NO into N2 and H2O (Eq. 4). In this section, we discuss several possible reaction pathways involving these steps based on the energy profiles and corresponding structures, which are presented in Figs. 3–5. The E a values and imaginary frequencies of each elementary step are summarized in Table S1. (2) Step 1 (NH3 dissociation): NH3 → NH2 + H (3) Step 2 (NH2NO formation): NH2 + NO → NH2OH (4) Step 3 (NH2NO decomposition): NH2NO → N2 + H2O 3.3.1 NH3 dissociation and NH2NO formation on the anatase TiO2 (001) surface On the TiO2 (001) surface, the dissociative adsorption of NH3 occurs with a low activation energy barrier (E a) of 61.1 kJ/mol, and an imaginary frequency of 273i cm−1 was obtained for the reaction coordinate. After NH3 dissociation, a hydroxyl group is formed, and NH2 is bound to a Ti5c site (INT2), as shown in Fig. 3. Then, NO interacts with the NH2 species to form the NH2NO intermediate. There are two possible pathways regarding the approach of NO: the LH or ER mechanism. In the ER mechanism, NO directly interacts with NH2 to form NH2NO at a Ti5c site (INT3), whereas in the LH mechanism, NO binds to another Ti5c site first and hops onto NH2 pre-adsorbed on the Ti5c site. Although NH2NO formation via the LH pathway cannot be ruled out because of its low energy barrier (32.3 kJ/mol), the ER pathway is barrierless. Therefore, we consider the ER pathway for the NH2NO formation here. Subsequently, NH2NO transforms from a distorted NH2NO structure (INT3) to a planar structure (INT4), which is more stable than INT3 by about 43.4 kJ/mol. The energy barrier for this step is 14.5 kJ/mol. In INT4, H3 (Fig. 3) of NH2 interacts with an O2c site on the surface separated by 1.83 Å. 3.3.2 NH2NO decomposition to N2 and H2O on the anatase TiO2 (001) surface In the next step, the decomposition of NH2NO into N2 and H2O, which is typically represented as NH2NO → NHNOH → N2 + H2O, was examined. We considered two possible mechanisms: the non-surface-assisted (nSA) and surface-assisted (SA) mechanisms, as shown in Figs. 4 and 5, respectively. In the nSA mechanism, the direct intramolecular transfer of H atoms occurs, whereas, in the SA mechanism, the reaction proceeds via an H-atom-exchange process between the surface O2c sites and adsorbate species. 3.3.2.1 Non-surface-assisted mechanism In the nSA mechanism, the decomposition of NH2NO into N2 and H2O occurs through intramolecular hydrogen transfer (Fig. 4). This route starts from the step in which the H2 atom of NH2NO transfers from the N atom to the O atom to form the NHNOH structure and has a high energy barrier of 150.5 kJ/mol as a result of the formation of a four-membered-ring transition state. Thus, we presume that this reaction does not occur under low-temperature conditions. The next step involves rotation about the NN and NO bonds (E a =79.2 kJ/mol), which is required to achieve another H transfer. The subsequent formation of N2 and H2O as products has a high energy barrier of 154.5 kJ/mol at TS5. Thus, this step is the largest barrier in this pathway. Finally, the INT7→FS1 step represents the desorption of N2 and H2O molecules from the (001) surface with one H remaining on the surface. 3.3.2.2 Surface-assisted mechanism As an alternative to the nSA mechanism, the SA mechanism can be achieved by hydrogen transfer to the surface via three possible pathways. The first pathway is path 2B, whose energy profile is presented by the blue line in Fig. 5. First, H3 transfers from the NH2NO intermediate to the surface (INT4) to form NHNO (INT8); this process has an energy barrier of 20.4 kJ/mol. In the two subsequent steps, the interaction of NHNO with the surface changes, and the adsorbed molecule rotates, as shown in steps INT8→TS7→INT9 and INT9→TS8→INT10; the energy barriers (E a) for these two processes are 41.1 and 35.4 kJ/mol, respectively. Then, H2 dissociates onto the O2c site in the INT10→TS9→INT11 step, which has an energy barrier of 22.5 kJ/mol. Finally, N2 is detached from the surface to generate the product. Path 2C is presented by the red line in Fig. 5. Similar to path 2B, path 2C starts from INT4 and then transforms into INT8. Next, the intramolecular transfer of H2 occurs from the N terminal to the O terminal to form NNOH (INT12) via TS10. This step has an energy barrier of 154.5 kJ/mol. Next, the N2 OH bond is broken via TS11, which has an E a of approximately 18.3 kJ/mol. Thus, N2 is produced, but the OH fragment remains anchored to the Ti5c atom in INT13. The pathway shown by the green line in Fig. 5 represents the energy profile of path 2D. The first two steps, viz. INT4→INT8 and INT8→INT9, occur as in path 2B. In the subsequent step, the NO bond of NHNO (INT9) is broken, and H2 transfers to the O atom to form a new hydroxyl group on the surface (INT13) via TS12. The calculated activation barrier of the last step is 85.6 kJ/mol. By comparing the proposed pathways, path 2B was found to be the most favorable one for NH2NO decomposition on the (001) surface. The INT8→TS7→INT9 step has the largest barrier in this pathway but has a relatively low energy barrier of 41 kJ/mol. Overall, this reaction pathway is highly exothermic, having an overall energy of −316 kJ/mol. Thus, the pathway based on the SA mechanism is kinetically and thermodynamically preferable to the nSA mechanism. In particular, the low energy barriers and high exothermicity explain the experimentally observed low-temperature NH3-SCR of NO over TiO2-NSs [36]. All calculated energy values of the reaction pathways given in Figs. 3–5 are summarized in Table S1 in SI. Crucially, the O2c active sites on the (001) surface are key to this mechanism, facilitating H-transfer between the intermediates and the TiO2 surface. 3.4 NH3-SCR of NO on the anatase TiO2 (101) surface In this section, the NH3-SCR of NO over the (101) facet is considered. Similar to the reaction on the (001) surface, the three consecutive main steps (steps 1–3, Eqs. 2–4) are examined and compared with those on the (001) facet. In particular, we focus on the role of the O2c sites of the (101) surface. The energy profiles and corresponding structures are presented in Figs. 6 and 7. The E a values and imaginary frequencies of each elementary step are summarized in Table S2 in SI. 3.4.1 NH3 dissociation and NH2OH formation on the anatase TiO2 (101) surface First, the dissociation of NH3 on the TiO2 (101) facet was modeled. As shown in Fig. 6, the INT14→TS13→INT15 step has a high energy barrier of 151.0 kJ/mol and is endothermic by 118.3 kJ/mol relative to INT14. These values are in good agreement with the energy barrier of 125.4 kJ/mol reported by Ji et al. [10], and the result shows that this reaction is significantly different from that on the (001) surface. After NH3 dissociation, the NH2NO intermediate is formed, as shown in Fig. 6. On the approach of NO, the NH2 species reacts with NO to form NH2NO intermediate INT16. Then, INT16 is transformed to INT17 via TS14. The NH2NO intermediate is stabilized on the (101) facet, where the N atom of NO binds to the Ti5c site, and the O and H atoms form hydrogen bonds with the H and O2c atoms on the (101) surface. 3.4.2 NH2NO decomposition Two possible pathways for NH2NO decomposition on the (101) surface were examined. The energy profiles and relevant structures are shown in Fig. 7. Path 4A is shown by a red line; in this pathway, the SA mechanism occurs first via the INT17→TS15→INT18 step, which has an E a of 39.4 kJ/mol. The subsequent step proceeds via the INT18→TS16→INT19 step, which has an E a of 180.0 kJ/mol. The INT19→FS2 step represents the desorption of N2 and H2O molecules from the (101) surface with one H remaining on the surface. In path 4B, shown by the black line, NH2NO is first transformed to NHNOH via intermolecular H transfer (INT17→TS17→INT20), which has an E a of 155.7 kJ/mol. Then, the INT20→TS18→INT19 step occurs, which has an energy barrier of 42.0 kJ/mol. Comparing the largest activation energies of the proposed paths, we can see that path 4B is more favorable than path 4A. In particular, even if the energy barriers in the SA mechanism are low, the activation energies required for the intermolecular H transfer in the INT18→TS16→INT19 step of path 4A and INT4→TS4→INT5 step of path 4B remain high. Therefore, the NH2NO decomposition step has the largest activation barrier of the NH3-SCR of NO on the (101) facet. This result is also consistent with reported experimental results [61]. 3.5 Comparison of the NH3-SCR of NO on the anatase TiO2 (001) and (101) surfaces The energy profiles of the most favorable pathways for the NH3-SCR of NO on the (001) and (101) surfaces are compared in Fig. 8 . As discussed before, the two surfaces have distinct structural characteristics, such as the ratio of active sites (O2c and Ti5C) on the surface, electronic structure, and surface geometry. These unique characteristics result in reactivity differences between the (001) and (101) surfaces; specifically, the (001) surface is more active than the (101) surface, the binding energies for gas species on the (001) surface are larger than those on the (101) surface, and the O2c sites preferentially form hydroxyl groups by interaction with dissociated H atoms. These results imply the higher reactivity of the O2c sites of the (001) surface. Consequently, the dissociative adsorption of H2O and NH3 on the (001) surface is preferable to that on the (101) surface. In the literature, it has been proposed that the high reactivity of the (001) surface is related to the active O2c atoms on the surface and that the O2c atoms of the (101) surface are less reactive than those on the (001) surface [25,62]. In summary, the results presented herein reveal that not only the Ti sites but the active O2c sites also play a crucial role in the mechanism of the NH3-SCR of NO on the anatase TiO2 (001) surface, in which the reaction proceeds via the SA mechanism. The electronic structure, surface geometry, and the number of active sites are all key factors influencing the reactivity of the (001) surface. For example, the activation energy barrier for NH3 dissociation on the (001) facet is significantly reduced by ∼90 kJ/mol compared to that on the (101) surface. In the subsequent steps, hydrogen transfer from the intermediates to the surface O2c sites promotes the reaction. In addition, a reduction in the activation energy barriers was observed as a result of the reduced geometric constraints on the intermediates for intermolecular H transfer on the (001) surface. The NH3 dissociation step, which has a low energy barrier of 61 kJ/mol, is the largest barrier step of the NH3-SCR on (001). NH2NO decomposition in the SA mechanism is significantly more favorable, having an energy barrier of only 41 kJ/mol and being highly exothermic overall (−316 kJ/mol). The present findings are consistent with previous experimental results, in which the NH3-SCR of NO on TiO2-NSs was observed to occur at low temperatures [36]. Notably, we have revealed that it is the differences in the intrinsic characteristics of the active sites on the (001) and (101) surfaces that result in their differences in catalytic activity. Because the complete catalytic circle is very complex, we have only focused on how the active sites catalyze the standard NH3-SCR of NO, and other factors, including the effect of surface hydroxylation and the fast-SCR mechanism, must be investigated in future studies. 4 Conclusion In this paper, we have reported detailed insights into the origin of the superior catalytic performance of the anatase TiO2 (001) face observed in the NH3-SCR of NO using TiO2 nanosheets, which have dominant (001) faces. Crucially, the catalytic activity is significantly affected by the electronic structures, geometric characteristics, and the numbers of active sites on these two surfaces, which result in significantly different catalytic performances. The mechanism based on the SA reaction pathway is the predominant route for NH2NO decomposition on the (001) surface. In this process, the surface O sites are involved in the reaction and reduce the energy barriers of all the elementary steps. Thus, the NH2NO decomposition proceeds smoothly, and NH3 dissociation step has the largest activation barrier for the reaction on the (001) surface. However, we found that NH2NO decomposition has the largest barrier step of the (101) surface. The low energy barriers for the NH3-SCR of NO on the (001) surface and the high exothermicity of this reaction are consistent with the experimental observation of low-temperature activity. In conclusion, the high activity of the (001) surface can be explained by the presence and quantity of active O2c sites on the surface. The results reported herein are particularly relevant for the further design of high-performance metal oxide catalysts for the low-temperature NH3-SCR of NO. coredata.dc:description: Recently, the facet-dependent catalytic activity of anatase TiO2 for the selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 (NH3-SCR) has been observed experimentally. In this study, the NH3-SCR of NO on the TiO2 (001) and (101) surfaces was systematically investigated using dispersion-corrected density functional theory. We propose that the surface-assisted mechanism is predominant on the (001) surface, which involves the oxygen active sites playing a crucial role in facilitating the reaction. The NH3 dissociation step reveals the largest activation energy barrier (E a) of 61 kJ/mol on the (001) surface, whereas the NH2NO decomposition step has the largest barrier, E a ≈ 156 kJ/mol, on the (101) surface. The results obtained by calculation are consistent with the experimental results, which have shown that a TiO2 nanosheet with a dominant (001) facet shows superior catalytic performance in NH3-SCR of NO compared to TiO2 nanoparticles with dominant (101) facet.
coredata.dc:title: Facet-dependent catalytic activity of anatase TiO2 for the selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3: A dispersion-corrected density functional theory study
